etymologies: Old English swingan ‘to beat, whip’, also ‘rush’, geswing ‘a stroke with a weapon’, of Germanic origin; related to German schwingen ‘brandish’

definitions: move or cause to move back and forth or from side to side while suspended or on an axis

examples.text: her long black skirt swung about her legs
a priest began swinging a censer

shortDefinitions: move or cause to move back and forth or from side to side while suspended or on axis

definitions: be executed by hanging

examples.text: now he was going to swing for it

shortDefinitions: be executed by hanging

definitions: turn (a ship or aircraft) to all compass points in succession, in order to test compass error.
shortDefinitions: turn ship or aircraft to all compass points in succession

definitions: move by grasping a support from below and leaping

examples.text: we swung across like two trapeze artists
the Irishman swung himself into the saddle

notes.text: no object, with adverbial of direction

shortDefinitions: move by grasping support from below and leaping

definitions: move quickly around to the opposite direction

examples.text: Ronni had swung around to face him

shortDefinitions: move quickly round to opposite direction

definitions: move with a rhythmic swaying gait

examples.text: the riflemen swung along smartly

shortDefinitions: move with rhythmic swaying gait

definitions: move or cause to move in a smooth, curving line

examples.text: the cab swung into the parking lot
he swung her bag up onto the rack

shortDefinitions: move or cause to move in smooth

definitions: bring down (something held) with a curving movement, typically in order to hit an object

examples.text: I swung the club and missed the ball

shortDefinitions: bring down something held with curving movement

definitions: attempt to hit or punch, typically with a wide curving movement of the arm

examples.text: he swung at me with the tire iron

shortDefinitions: attempt to hit or punch

definitions: throw (a punch) with a swinging movement

examples.text: she swung a punch at him

shortDefinitions: deliver punch with wide curving movement of arm

definitions: shift or cause to shift from one opinion, mood, or state of affairs to another

examples.text: opinion swung in the Chancellor's favor
the failure to seek a peace could swing sentiment the other way

shortDefinitions: shift or cause to shift from one opinion, mood, or state of affairs

definitions: have a decisive influence on (something, especially a vote or election)

examples.text: an attempt to swing the vote in their favor

shortDefinitions: have decisive influence on

definitions: succeed in bringing about

examples.text: with us backing you we might be able to swing something

shortDefinitions: succeed in bringing about

definitions: play music with an easy flowing but vigorous rhythm

examples.text: the band swung on

shortDefinitions: play music with easy flowing but vigorous rhythm

definitions: (of music) be played with an easy flowing but vigorous rhythm.
shortDefinitions: (of music) be played with flowing but vigorous rhythm

definitions: (of an event, place, or way of life) be lively, exciting, or fashionable.
shortDefinitions: be lively or fashionable

definitions: engage in group sex or swap sexual partners within a group, especially on a habitual basis.
shortDefinitions: be promiscuous

phrases.text: get back into the swing of things
get into the swing of things
not room to swing a cat

definitions: a seat suspended by ropes or chains, on which someone may sit and swing back and forth.
shortDefinitions: seat suspended by ropes or chains, on which someone may sit and swing back and forth

definitions: a spell of swinging on a seat suspended by ropes or chains.
shortDefinitions: period of time spent swinging on seat suspended by ropes or chains

definitions: an act of swinging

examples.text: with the swing of her arm, the knife flashed through the air

shortDefinitions: act of swinging

definitions: the manner in which a golf club or a bat is swung

examples.text: improve your golf swing

shortDefinitions: manner in which golf club or bat is swung

definitions: the motion of swinging

examples.text: this short cut gave her hair new movement and swing

shortDefinitions: motion of swinging

definitions: a discernible change in opinion

examples.text: the South's swing to the right

shortDefinitions: discernible change in opinion

definitions: a style of jazz or dance music with an easy flowing but vigorous rhythm.
shortDefinitions: style of jazz or dance music with flowing but vigorous rhythm

definitions: the rhythmic feeling or drive of swing music.
shortDefinitions: rhythmic feeling or drive of swing

definitions: a swift tour involving a number of stops, especially one undertaken as part of a political campaign.
shortDefinitions: swift tour involving several stops

definitions: (in musical theater) an understudy, typically one who covers multiple roles in the chorus of a particular production.
shortDefinitions: (in musical theatre) an understudy

phrases.text: get back into the swing of things
get into the swing of things
not room to swing a cat
